module.p: bean touch, interfere/meddle/deal/tamper (with) is an intransitive durative verb, with verbal noun beantainn (alternative forms – beanail, beantail, beanailt).
cf. other uses of the word bean.

bean is derived from the Old Gaelic verb benaid beat, strike. It also seems to be the root of the static verb buin belong/pertain (to), and the two often get confused in modern Gaelic (as many of the examples cited below will make clear).

Imperative examples from dictionaries and grammars –
Buin gu caoimhneil ri m’ ghaol!
Deal gently with my love! td. 140
Na bean ris na buill-maise!
Don’t touch the ornaments! td. 43
Na buin da sin!
Do not touch that! td. 140
An rud nach buin duit, na buin da!
Do not meddle with what does not concern you! td. 140
